column11: Definition
column12: Example
column14: Editors Note

column11: AL iao:0000115@en
column12: AL iao:0000112@en
column14: AL iao:0000116@en

column11: A group of people recognized as such by people outside the group that come together for a purpose.
column12: A political party, a homeowners association, a football team, a publisher, a government agency, an organized religion

column5: ('company' or 'nonprofit organization' or 'informal organization' or 'organization part')
column11: An organization which is the body of persons that constitutes the governing authority of a political unit
column12: The State of Florida is recognized as a government organization by the United States.  The government of the United States is recognized by other governments.  Note there is no "part of" relationship here.  Each is a government organization.

column5: ('government organization' or 'nonprofit organization' or 'informal organization' or 'organization part')
column11: A legal entity of associated persons created for a specific purpose, typically commercial, in which excess revenue may be distributed to the company's owners.
column12: BASF, The University of Phoenix, Facebook, Elsevier, Apple, Google, Amazon

column5: ('government organization' or 'company' or 'informal organization' or 'organization part')
column11: A legal entity of associated persons created for a specific purpose, typically a mission, in which excess revenue is reinvested to serve the entity's mission
column12: Doctors Without Borders, Duke University, The American Medical Association

column5: ('government organization' or 'company' or 'nonprofit organization' or 'organization part')
column11: A group of people recognized as such by people outside the group. Without legal standing.
column12: A student club, a university committee, the VIVO Ontology Interest Group
column14: There are many names associated with informal organizations including club, group, party, team, cell, task force, work group, interest group, meeting, and roundtable.  These could potentially be differentiated with class expressions involving dispositions and/or qualities in the future.

column5: ('government organization' or 'company' or 'nonprofit organization' or 'informal organization')
column11: An organization which exists as part of another organization.  Implies a part_of relationship to another organization
column12: The US Navy is an organizational part of the US Department of Defense.  The History Department is an organizational part of its college

column11: A disposition to award academic degrees and conduct research in a variety of academic disciplines
column12: The University of Bologna is an organization that has a university disposition
column14: Some dispositions may well be functions -- the organization does not exist without it.

column11: A disposition to organize organizations or individuals along and industry or academic lines
column12: The American Medical Association; The AFL-CIO; The Institution of Railway Signal Engineers

column11: A disposition to organize organizations along industry or academic lines
column12: The Association of Research Libraries; The NIH Common Fund Metabolomics Consortium
column14: The word "association" in english may mean many diffierent things.  Often consortiums have the word "association" in their title.

column11: A disposition to provide service with or without a fee
column12: A hospital has a service provider disposition to provide medical services to patients
column14: We can expect to have many types of service provider dispositions

column11: A disposition to provide laboratory services.  In the US, organization parts in universities that have a disposition to provide laboratory services to others are called core laboratories
column12: The Interdisciplinary Center for Biotechnology Rsearch is a part of the university with a disposition to offer laboratory services to others
column14: The word "core laboratory" may indicate that an organization has a disposition of laboratory services

column11: A disposition to provide extension services, typically in agriculture.  Extension provides access to university research findings and advice to agriculturalists.
column12: Texas A&M Agrilife Extension is a part of the university with a disposition for providing agricultural exteension services
column14: Extension is most commonly used to describe agircultural extension services.

column11: A disposition to create licenses for intellectual property for use by these beyond the creators
column12: The Duke Office of Licensing and Ventures has a technology transfer disposition

column11: A disposition to donate charitable causes, sometimes in the form of grants involving contracts regarding the use of the donated funds or effort.
column12: The Wellcome Trust, The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, The Sierra Club have dispositions of philanthropy

column11: A disposition to fund proposals, often is response to a call for proposals by the entity with the funding disposition
column12: The National Institutes of Health (NIH) and The National Science Foundation (NSF) have funder dispositions

column11: A disposition to provider health care to humans
column12: A nurse has a disposition to provide health care servces

column11: A disposition to provide hospital-based health care services to humans
column12: Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York has a disposition to provide hospital services

column11: A disposition to collect, store, and provide access to inanimate material entities, and/or information content entitites
column12: The British Museum has a disposition to archive, particularly works of the United Kingdom
column14: We might expect to have refinements of this disposition as special cases

column11: A disposition to collect, store, and provide access to inanimate material entities in a facility
column12: The National Portrait Gallery is an art museum

column11: A disposition to display collected works from an archive
column12: The Color Factory in New York City is an art gallery
column14: The distinction between an art gallery and and art museum has to do with the temporary nature of displays in galleries, as well as the common practice in galleries to sell art on display

column11: A disposition to publish information content entities
column12: Random House, Taylor and Francis, The American Pyschological Association, The University of California Berkeley has a disposition to publish

column11: A disposition to conduct research
column12: The Max Plank Institute, Northwestern University, CERN (the European Organization for Nuclear Research) have have a disposition to conduct research

column11: A disposition to teach, and provide experiential opprtunities for students
column12: A pre-school education program, a post-graduate education program, adult education programs all have education dispositions

column11: A disposition to train, and provide experiential opportunities for trainees
column12: A military training program, a flight school training program, a CPR training program all have dispositions to train

column11: A disposition to provide resources and oversight for those conducting research
column12: The Office of Research at a university typically does not conduct research, it has a disposition to administer research

column11: A disposition to provide library services
column12: The Library of Congress, the local public library, a university library all have dispositions of library
column14: Perhaps a function

column11: A disposition to sell things
column12: Google, Tesla, General Electric, BASF, AstraZeneca all have a disposition to sell things

column11: A disposition to engage in warfare
column12: The US Space Force, the Chinese Navy, and the Bolivian Army are example of organizations with miltary disposition
column14: Perhaps a function

column11: A disposition to engage in matters of spirtuality and faith
column12: The Catholic Church, a local synagogue, a mosque, a buudhist monestary have a relgisious disposition
column14: Perhaps a function.

column11: A disposition to provide governance
column12: A Board of Trustees, A Board of Directors, the Senate of the United States all have governing dispositions

column11: A dispositon to construct material entities
column12: Volkswagon, Apple, Pfizer, Airbus, BASF, Nestle, and General Electric all have manufacturing dispositions

column11: A disposition to execute and finish a project.
column12: A book writing team, a grant writing team, a time-limited work group, and a conference organizing committee all have a project team disposition
column14: Organization may be formal or informal.

column11: A disposition to engage in sports activites, typically competitive.
column12: The University of Alabama mens football team, Manchester United, the Mumbai Indians Cricket Team are all organizations with a disposition of sports
column14: Perhaps a function

column11: A quality of an address to be used for information inquiries
column12: Email addresses that begin help@ info@ contact@ often have information address address disposition

column11: A quality of an address to be used to receive bills
column12: Bills may be sent to Attn: Name at

column11: A quality of an address to be used to receive shipped goods
column12: The loading dock address for central receiving of an organization

column11: A quality of an address to be displayed in most settings
column12: The address the organization displays most prominently in promotional materials

column11: A quality to be the primary website for an entity.
column12: The home page of Harvard is https://harvard.edu

column11: A quality to be the webpage within WikiPedia regarding the entity
column12: The Wikipedia page of Harvard is https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard_University

column11: A material entity that is a human made strcuture with firm connection between its foundation and the ground.
column12: Yankee Stadium, Stonehenge, The Shard, The Large Hadron Collider. The Great Wall of China
column14: Perhaps identical to the term in OMRSE

column11: The geographic location consisting of the  grounds or property of a school, college, university, business, church, or hospital, often understood to include buildings and other structures.
column12: The campus of Oxford University, the campus of Microsoft in Redmond, Washington, the NIH campus in Bethesda, Maryland.

column11: An architectural structure that bears some function.
column12: Walt Disney World, Kennedy Space Center, Golden Gate Bridge
column14: Perhaps identical to the term in OMRSE

column11: A permanent walled and roofed construction
column12: The Pentagon, The Leaning Tower of Pisa, The Gherkin, The Coliseum
column14: Similar to the term in ENVRO, but based on 'architectural structure' in OMRSE

column11: A space contained by a partitioned part of the inside of a building.  Often has an identifier.
column12: The Oval Office is a room in the White House.  A classroom, a locker room, a bedroom, a kitchen are all rooms.
column14: A room is not a structure.  It is a space inside a structure.

column11: A place on the earth.  Not necessarily contiguous
column12: The Indian Ocean, Africa, Metropolitan France, West 57th Street
column14: 1. Geographical locations are often confused with the entities that are located in those places.  For example, France is a country with several discontiguous geographical loctions.  Metropolitan France is a geographical location in Europe.  2. Unlike the GAZ term, this term is not a reference to a place on the earth, rather it is a place on the earth.

column11: A point located on the earth
column12: The point with latitude 27.9881199 and longitude 86.9161989
column14: 1. Since a point is smaller than a building, we say the point is located in a building.  The building is the location of the point.  2. Typically use ORG_0000004 to provide a lat/long value for the point.

column11: One of the main landmasses of the globe, usually reckoned as seven in number (Europe, Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Australia, and Antarctica).
column12: Asia, Europe, Antarctica, North America, South America, Africa, and Oceania are the continents
column14: Should define 7 named individuals and then this class is explicitly defined

column11: The territory governed by a sovereign state.
column12: Canada, Ecuador, Slovakia, Namibia, Pakistan, New Zealand are all countries
column14: This term is about the territory, not the geopolitical entity of the same name.

column11: A subdivision of the territory of a country
column12: US states, counties, Candian Provinces, US Zip codes, US SMSAs, US time zone territories are all examples of regions.
column14: This term is about the territory, not its governance.  It could be subclassed to define verious types of regions -- census tracts, zip codes, and others.

column11: A named place on the earth occupied by people
column12: Tokyo Japan, Eustis Florida, Podgorica Montenegro, and Stevenage United Kingdom are all populated places.
column14: There is wide variation in the applicaton of this term.

column11: The process by which the organization was founded
column12: The United States government was founded by the constitutional convention process of 1787 resulting in a ratified constitution in 1790
column14: The founding process might by a subproperty of a generic creation process if such a process ever appears at a higher level in the ontologies

column11: The process boundary which defines the moment of creation of an orgnization.  Before the moment  the organization does not exist.  After the moment, the organization exists.
column12: The University of Bologna was founded in 1088.  Facebook was founded in 2004.

column11: The process by which an organization no longer exists.
column12: The German Democratic Republic (aka East Germany) ended in 1990.
column14: There are many dissolution processes (merger, acquisition, discontinuation).  These can be added at a later date if needed.

column11: The process boundary which marks the moment at which the organization no longer exists
column12: Duraspace ceased to exist on July 1, 2019
column14: The dissolution process may have many steps and boundaries, such as ceasing operations, transfer of funds, dissolution of board.  These can be added at a later date if needed.

column11: The process by which one organization gores out of existence and is succeeded by a new organization
column12: The Central People's Government of the People's Republic of China was proclaimed by Mao Zedong on October 1, 1949 at 3PM replacing the government of the Republic of China.
column14: The succession process typically has founding and dissolution processes as occurent parts

column11: The process boundary within a succession process.  Complex succesion processes may have many boundaries.
column12: East Timor became a formally independent country on 20 May 2002

column11: The information content entity consisting of a group of World Wide Web pages usually containing hyperlinks to each other and made available online by an individual, company, educational institution, government, or organization
column12: Facebook and Google have prominent web sites.

column11: The process by which one organization spins off of another
column12: Google is the output of a spin-off process in which Stanford University was a participant

column11: The boundary of a spin-off process
column12: Spin-off process boundaries include moments such as incorporation, board formation, funding ac quisition, and patent licensing

column11: The asymmetric relationship involving two organizations in which one is a member of the other
column12: Texas A&M University is an organizational member of the Association of Public and Land Grant Universities
column14: Organizational Membership is a Membership, which is a Relationship, which is an Occurrent.  The subsumption is out of scope for the Organizationa Ontology. The existence of a membership implies the existence of a membership creation process and a membership creation process boundary.  These are currently out of scope for the Organization Ontology

column11: The role of an organization in being a member of another
column12: The University of aToronto has organizational membership role which is realized in a membership granted by the American Association of Universities

column11: The role of an organization in granting a member role to another
column12: Most membership organizations grant theoir memberships to their members

column11: The quality of an organization that is led by a student
column12: The student chess club, the student data science club, the student newspaper may all be student-led organizations
column14: Student-led organizations may be formal or informal

column11: The quality of an organization that is led by a woman
column12: As of 2021, The Office of the Vice President of the United States, and the Federal Government of Germany are women-led organizations
column14: In some jurisdictions, such as the US, counting women-led organizations is important

column11: The quality of an organiztion that is led by a designated minority
column12: From 2008-2016, the Office of the President of the United States was a minority-led organization
column14: In some jurisdictions, such as the US, counting minority-led organizations is important

column11: The quality of a location that is the legal/registered location for the organization
column12: The legal registered location for Google is Mountain View, California

column11: The quality of a location that is the primary/preferred location for the organization
column12: The primary site for Microsoft is Redmond, Washington

column11: The asymmetric relationship between an organization and a person in which a person has a role in the positon, as does the organization.
column12: A university may have a position of chancellor, which is then filled by a person
column14: The organization and the person in the position relationship each have roles with respect to the position relationship

column11: The role of a person to be an employee of an organization
column12: Walt Disney was an employee of the United States Post Office

column11: The role of an organization to employ a person
column12: McDonalds once employed Jeff Bezos

column11: The role of a person to be an associate of an organization
column12: Bill Gates is an associate of Microsoft, even though he is no longer employed there

column11: The role of an organization to grant associate status to a person
column12: A university may grant various forms of associate status to people who are not formally associated with the university
column14: This is a role of an organization, not a person within the organization

column11: The role of a person to be the head of an organization
column12: Joey Wat is the head of Yum China

column11: The role of an organization to grant head status to a person
column12: The board of trustees of a company often grants the head of role
column14: This is a role of an organization, not a person within the organization

column11: The role of a person to be an appointee of an organization
column12: Jorge Mario Bergoglio was appointed to the position Pope by the papal conclave of the College of Cardinals of the Catholic Church in 2013

column11: The role of an organization to grant appointee status to a person
column12: The members of a chess club may elect one of their members to serve as secretary
column14: This is a role of an organization, not a person within the organization

column11: The role of a person to be a volunteer of an organization
column12: Lillian Carter, the mother of US president Jimmy Carter, served as a peace corps volunteer in India

column11: The role of an organization to grant volunteer status to a person
column12: A hospital has a volunteer grantor role with respect to those persons who volunteer at the hospital
column14: This is a role of an organization, not a person within the organization

column11: The disposition of an organization that operates airplanes carrying frieght or passengers
column12: Delta, Lufthanza, and Aeroflot all have airline disposition
column14: Added for completeness with schema.org

column11: The disposition of an organization that creates, transmits, and/or licenses live or recorded material for viewing by others
column12: NBC, BBC, CNN, EFE News Agency and the Japan Times all have media dispositions
column14: Added for completeness with schema.org

column11: The disposition of an organization to perform live or recorded music, theatre, or dance
column12: The Bolshoi Ballet, the Royal Shakespeare Company, the local community theater, the Metropolitan Opera are all organizations with performing disposition
column14: Added for completeness with schema.org

column11: The disposition of an organization to organize workers for the purpose of negotiations with employers of the workers
column12: All-China Federation of Trade Unions (ACFTU), the Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU) and the General Confederation of Labor (CGT) in France are all organizations with disposition of labor union.
column14: Added for completeness with schema.org

column11: The asymmetric relationship representing a person's membership in an organization
column12: One might have a membership in Doctors Without Borders

column11: The role of a person to be a member of an organization
column12: George Harrison had a person member role with respect to The Beatles

column11: The role of an organization to grant membership to a person
column12: Professional societies have a grantor role with respect to their members

column11: The disposition of an organization part to serve as an academic department, with faculty, courses, programs, focused on an academic discipline
column12: The Mathematics Department at Nanjing University, the Philosophy Department at Stanford have disposition academic department

column11: The disposition of an organization part to serve as an academic college, with academic departments organized within it as parts
column12: The College of the Arts at the University of Florida has a disposition academic college

column11: The disposition of an organization part to serve as a a body of persons delegated to consider, investigate, take action on, or report on some matter
column12: A board of trustees may have a finance committee to review and approve budgets.
column14: Committees may be standing.  Project Teams are expected to finish their work.

column11: The disposition of an organization to provide education for very young children, varying by jurisdiction, but often in the age range 2-5
column12: La Petite Academy is a chain of commercial preschools operating in the United States

column11: The disposition of an organization to provide education for young children, varying by jurisdiction, but often in the age range 5-11
column12: Prince Charles attended Hill House, and elemntary school in West London

column8: junior high school|intermediate school|lower secondary school
column11: The disposition of an organization to provide education for children, varying by jurisdiction, but often in the age range 11-14
column12: Community Day Charter School is a middle school in Lawrence, Massachusetts

column11: The disposition of an organization to provide education for older children, varying by jurisdiction, but often in the age range 14-18
column12: Institut Le Rosey in Switzerland is a famous secondary school having educated children of the Rothchilds, Hohenzollerns, and many monarchs

column11: The disposition of an organization to be in current existence and currently operational
column12: Microsoft is active

column11: The disposition of an organization to no longer exist, or to be currently devoid of operations
column12: The League of Nations is inactive
